Methodology: The study used linear and nonlinear multiple regression, 15-year moving windows, and the Mann-Kendall test to analyze GPP trends from 1982-2015, utilizing satellite GPP proxies, EC flux tower data (excluding sites with large land cover changes), satellite-based LAI, CCDAS GPP data, the EC-LUE model, TRENDY model simulations, a linear spatial mixed-effects model (to link GPP trends with foliar nutrient concentrations), and terrestrial water storage data, analyzing different climate zones to explore the temporal dynamics of CFE at a global scale.
Highlights: Satellite data, models, and experiments indicate a declining global CO2 fertilization effect (CFE) from 1982-2015, resulting in reduced carbon uptake and land-based climate mitigation potential, with current models potentially underestimating the magnitude and sensitivity of this decline to water availability and nutrient limitations, implying future warming may be underestimated.
More Notes: Declining trends in the carbon fertilization effect (β) are evident across various climate zones and vegetation types, particularly in grasslands and cold climates, with slightly smaller decreases in tropical regions. The decline is attributed to both direct effects on foliar physiology and indirect effects on the leaf area index (LAI), with water availability limitations and environmental factors like nutrient deposition influencing certain areas, while increases in croplands may be driven by management practices.
Adaptation considered: Adaptation not explicitly considered in the methodology. Focus is on trends in GPP using models, satellite data, and flux tower data. Water availability (TWS) is used as a variable influencing GPP, but not in the context of adaptive strategies.

Paper Title: The social costs of tropical cyclones
Outcome(s) of Interest: Increased social cost of carbon; Underestimated benefits of climate policies; Insufficient representation of tropical cyclone damage.
Drivers of Risk: TC frequency & intensity, global mean temperature, population exposure, socioeconomic pathways (SSPs), probabilistic TC time series.
Methodology: The study derives temperature-dependent damage functions for 41 TC-affected countries to quantify the country-level SCC. It uses a three-way fixed effects panel model to estimate national GDPpc growth responses, incorporating national shares of people exposed to TCs and temperature impacts. Scenario analysis and probabilistic methods (bootstrapping, TC impact emulator) are used to project TC damages from 2010-2100, considering uncertainty dimensions like future emissions, socioeconomic development, discounting, historical growth response, TC impact response, and temperature response. A mixed-effects model is used to derive temperature-dependent damage functions by regressing growth rate changes on changes in global mean temperature, and to examine the relationship between global temperature changes and cyclone-induced economic losses, across multiple RCP scenarios. It uses the impact assessment tool CLIMADA to generate wind footprints for TC tracks. The SCC is calculated using a coupled carbon-climate convolution integral approach, following Ricke et al. (2018). The analysis utilizes 7,200,000 realizations per country and is implemented in Python, using CLI-MADA and statsmodels, with openly available code.
Highlights: Tropical cyclones (TCs) significantly increase the social cost of carbon (SCC), with a median global rise from US$ 173 to US$ 212 per ton of CO2, highlighting underestimated climate policy benefits. TC impacts, distinct from temperature effects, lead to varied growth losses, affecting high-income nations despite adaptation. These impacts escalate SCC notably under scenarios like RCP8.5, with major emitters and various income-level countries facing critical adaptation challenges.
More Notes: The increased global SCC is driven by India, USA, China, Taiwan, and Japan; the model uses 8 lag years and four climate models; analysis uses country-level economic data; damages may be underestimated by neglecting adaptation, rainfall, and storm surge; temperature data from GSWP3-W5E5.
Adaptation considered: Adaptation is not explicitly modeled or discussed in the provided notes. The analysis focuses on quantifying TC-related damages and associated uncertainties under different climate scenarios, but does not include any representation of adaptive responses to these impacts.

Paper Title: Advancing the estimation of future climate impacts within the United States
Outcome(s) of Interest: Net national damages increase over time; significant long-term damages to human health (mortality from temperature and air pollution); regional variations (Southeast highest per capita, Southwest lowest); exacerbation of existing inequalities (disproportionate impact on Black/African Americans); detailed distribution of climate change impacts within US borders.
Drivers of Risk: Temperature change, sea level rise, air quality (O3, PM2.5), wildfire, high-tide flooding, dust, tropical storms/wind strength.
Methodology: The study employs the reduced-complexity model FrEDI, driven by climate projections from the FaIR model and socioeconomic projections from RFF-SP (10,000 scenarios covering emissions, population, and GDP), to project climate damages. It utilizes temperature binning, regional damage functions derived from GCMs, and a semi-empirical method for sea level rise estimation. The analysis incorporates parametric uncertainty in damage functions via Monte Carlo methods, assesses vulnerability across demographic groups, considers both constant and Ramsey discounting approaches, models adaptation (both historically practiced and proactive/reactive for coastal flooding), and extends projections to 2300 to calculate the net present value of damages from marginal changes in GHG emissions, using a 3% social rate of time preference.
Highlights: Highlights: National climate damages increase over time, with health impacts (temperature-related mortality and air quality) being the largest contributor; infrastructure is also a major concern; damages vary geographically, with the Southeast experiencing the highest per capita damages and the Southwest the lowest; Black/African Americans are disproportionately affected by air quality impacts, while Hispanic/Latino Americans face greater labor losses; adaptation can both increase or decrease damages; most sectors show increasing impacts through 2100, except for winter recreation; thresholds can trigger sharp damage increases; significant disparities in climate impacts exist for racial minorities and vulnerable groups.
More Notes: FrEDI model projects increasing net national damages, reaching $2.9 trillion annually by 2090, with the Southeast experiencing the highest per capita damages and the Southwest the lowest; projections don't account for climate-induced migration, are sensitive to emissions/socioeconomic projections and damage functions, and may involve double-counting or underestimation of compounding effects; adaptation is considered in some sectors but not all; the study uses 10,000 projections across sectors and regions, providing a range of outcomes.
Adaptation considered: FrEDI incorporates some adaptation assumptions from underlying sectoral studies and models proactive and reactive adaptation scenarios for coastal flooding. It reflects historically practiced adaptation. The framework can be updated with new sectoral studies. Damage estimates reflect year-specific socioeconomic conditions, with adjustments based on demographic changes or per capita damage rates. However, explicit adaptation modeling options are lacking in some sectors.

Paper Title: Near-term transition and longer-term physical climate risks of greenhouse gas emissions pathways
Outcome(s) of Interest: Physical risks (heatwaves, drought, heat stress, crop impacts) dependent on temperature pathway by 2050; Transition risks (mitigation costs, carbon prices, fossil fuel demand, coal plant capacity) sensitive to temperature pathways by 2030.
Drivers of Risk: GHG emissions, temperature pathways, socio-economic factors, technology, policy, fossil fuel demand, coal plant capacity, carbon prices, carbon intensity, land use policy, behavior changes, heatwaves, drought, flooding, heat stress, crop duration, transition to low-carbon economy, electricity decarbonization, electrification, reduced industrial demand, efficient buildings, transport behavior, consumption patterns, crop practices, afforestation.
Methodology: Integrated assessment and physical impacts models (GCAM, MAGICC, and a suite of impact models) are used to explore near-term transition (to 2030) and longer-term physical (to 2050) risks under different emissions pathways (1.5-4°C warming targets). The methodology combines a technology-rich, regionally disaggregated IAM with a reduced complexity climate model and impacts models, generating risk-related output indicators at a 0.5x0.5 degree resolution, then aggregated to regional scales. Scenarios explore variations in socio-economic pathways and technology assumptions (renewables, CCS, nuclear) and account for uncertainty in climate sensitivity and carbon cycle feedbacks. Metrics are normalized to a 2°C central scenario, with a 1981-2010 baseline. Physical risk indicators include heatwaves, agricultural drought, heat stress, and crop duration reductions, while transition risks are assessed via emissions, energy, and cost metrics.
Highlights: Highlights: Analyzes near-term transition and long-term physical climate risks under various emissions pathways (1.5-4°C warming), highlighting the dependence of physical risks by 2050 and transition risks by 2030 on temperature pathways, while transition risks also depend on technology, policy, and socio-economic factors; demonstrates that scenarios with similar long-term physical risks can have different near-term transition risks, and scenarios aimed at the same temperature goal can have considerably different transition risks by 2030; examines risks like heatwaves, drought, heat stress impacting maize yields, mitigation costs, carbon prices, and fossil fuel demand under different scenarios, including a "no policy" scenario leading to 4.3°C warming, and various 2°C and 1.5°C pathways involving technological and behavioral changes, and regional approaches; emphasizes the importance of integrated risk assessment for building further analysis.
More Notes: Analysis assesses transition and physical climate risks to 2050 globally and in key regions (including US), noting regional variations in river flooding and drought impacts; avoids economy-wide damage estimates due to uncertainties, focusing on heatwaves, drought, and heat stress; highlights the importance of technology, policy, and socio-economic factors, acknowledging that adaptation measures and low-carbon investment stimulus are not explicitly considered; the analysis assumes constant cropland area and complements NGFS scenarios, funded by ClimateWorks Foundation and the European Commission.
Adaptation considered: Adaptation isn't explicitly mentioned. The study focuses on analyzing physical climate risks under different emissions scenarios using integrated assessment models and physical impacts models, primarily focusing on mitigation and transition risks. The modeling framework incorporates socioeconomic pathways and technological assumptions, but adaptation strategies are not discussed.

Paper Title: The effect of rainfall changes on economic production
Outcome(s) of Interest: Reduced economic growth rates due to increased wet days and extreme daily rainfall, particularly in high-income nations and services/manufacturing sectors.
Drivers of Risk: Total annual rainfall, monthly rainfall deviations, number of wet days, extreme daily rainfall, variability, temperature.
Methodology: Fixed-effects panel regression models are used to estimate the effect of daily rainfall distribution on subnational economic growth rates, utilizing a global panel of 1,554 regions over 40 years (1979-2019); analysis includes assessing the impact of rainfall distribution (number of wet days, extreme daily rainfall exceeding various thresholds including the 99.9th percentile, total annual rainfall, and standardized monthly rainfall anomalies), controlling for factors like temperature, and accounting for region and year fixed effects, region-specific time trends, and spatial autocorrelation; sector-specific (agriculture, manufacturing, services) and income-level heterogeneity are also considered with standard errors clustered regionally or nationally, and marginal effects are calculated.
Highlights: Economic growth is negatively impacted by increased wet days and extreme daily rainfall. High-income nations and service/manufacturing sectors are most vulnerable. Rainfall's effects are greatest in winter/autumn, with wet days and negative monthly rainfall deviations causing the largest economic impacts. Impacts vary regionally and are strongest in Southeast Asia and parts of South America. The effect of wet days is nonlinear and dependent on income level. Agriculture, manufacturing, and service sectors exhibit varied growth responses to rainfall metrics.
More Notes: Study uses ERA-5 precipitation data, considers adaptation to wet days and heavy rainfall, identifies temperature-dependent regional heterogeneity in extreme rainfall impacts, assesses seasonal economic vulnerability to rainfall using 1979-2019 data and within-region standard deviations, focuses on historical means and distributions, and provides publicly available code and data with adjusted R-squared values provided as a measure of model fit.
Adaptation considered: Adaptation isn't explicitly considered in the methodology. The analysis focuses on historical relationships between rainfall patterns and economic outcomes using fixed-effects panel regression and related econometric techniques. It does, however, explore differential impacts based on income levels and economic sectors which could indirectly inform adaptation strategies.

Paper Title: Capturing uncertainty when modelling environmental drivers of fish populations, with an illustrative application to Pacific Cod in the eastern Bering Sea
Outcome(s) of Interest: Pacific cod biomass declines; reduced catch; lower fishery profits; potential stock conservation with conservative harvest control rules based on worst-case climate scenario.
Drivers of Risk: Temperature increase, model uncertainty, emissions scenarios, environmental variables, SST, recruitment, growth, climate scenarios, fishing mortality, biomass, Pacific cod, natural mortality, trophic interactions, spawning area expansion, climate dynamics.
Methodology: The methodology involves climate-enhanced stock assessments driven by Earth System Models, generating future catch series based on multiple assessment model configurations, environmental scenarios, and harvest control rules. A Bayesian approach (NUTS MCMC) is used for parameter estimation, with model selection based on AIC. Projections account for structural model uncertainty (assessment model configuration, Earth System Models/emission scenarios, climate coupling), parameter uncertainty, and process error in recruitment. The framework is applied to Pacific cod in the eastern Bering Sea, projecting stock status and fishery performance under different climate scenarios and harvest strategies, considering both time-varying and pre-specified parameters. Multiple assessment model configurations from the US North Pacific Fishery Management Council are used, some assuming future recruitment independent of environmental links. The study examines harvest control rules (e.g., 40-5, constant F) and catch limits from various climate scenarios (e.g., MIROC ssp126, GFDL ssp585), acknowledging the assumption of stationarity in environment-recruitment relationships and 'set and forget' management.
Highlights: Climate change (increased temperature) increases weight-at-age for Pacific cod in the eastern Bering Sea but reduces recruitment, with the negative effects on recruitment outweighing the positive effects on weight-at-age; environmental scenarios significantly impact spawning biomass projections, more so than assessment model configuration; current harvest control rules may not conserve the stock if future environmental impacts are ignored, potentially leading to population collapse under higher catch scenarios; basing future catches on the poorest-outcome climate scenario (GFDL ssp585) generally maintains the stock above a critical threshold and achieves long-term profits; model and Earth System Model uncertainty are significant and influence assessment outcomes; climate-enhanced stock assessments and regular reviews of environmental variable-population parameter relationships are crucial for climate-sensitive stocks.
More Notes: Eastern Bering Sea Pacific cod stock assessment was used as an example, acknowledging parameter limitations, low explained variance of environmental drivers, and varying performance of assessment models depending on environmental scenario; assessment model configuration has less impact on risk than accounting for environmental drivers in catch limits; climate change impacts differ more significantly across models after mid-21st century; southern Bering Sea spawning area expansion contrasts with northern Bering Sea reduction due to marine heatwaves; analysis excludes biological adaptation and links increased temperature to metabolic demand, mortality, and prey limitations; projections assume harvest matches catch limits.
Adaptation considered: Adaptation is considered through harvest control rules that adjust catch limits based on projected stock status and environmental scenarios. Different control rules are tested, often using a 40-5 rule. However, the paper notes a limitation in assuming "set and forget" management and suggests future research should consider adaptive management strategies and feedback control. One set of projections assumed future recruitment without environmental links.

Paper Title: Direct measurement forest carbon protocol: a commercial system-of-systems to incentivize forest restoration and management
Outcome(s) of Interest: Increased carbon revenue, economic incentives for deforestation reversal, and reduced risk of invalidation in carbon markets.
Drivers of Risk: Forest carbon sequestration uncertainty, fire, deforestation, intentional/unintentional reversals, GHG emissions, market prices, ecosystem vulnerabilities, currency fluctuations, extreme weather, climate change, anthropogenic activity, drought, carbon-negative to carbon-positive switch, soil carbon efflux.
Methodology: DMFCP methodology involves direct, in-situ measurement of net ecosystem exchange (NEE) of CO2 using eddy covariance and analyzers for CO2 isotopologues and greenhouse gases, deployed across a project landscape within a System-of-Systems (SoS) network architecture and Global Monitoring Platforms (GMPs); NEE data is extrapolated to larger areas, combined with spatial/temporal data, and used to forecast carbon revenue; the methodology uses publicly available annual NEE data, considers third-party validation, and uses ton-year accounting and potentially uses remote sensing data to improve the extrapolation from towers, and MODIS and AmeriFlux data may be combined.
Highlights: DMFCP (Direct Measurement Forest Carbon Protocol) aims to monetize sustainable forest management by directly measuring forest CO2 fluxes for carbon trading and reporting, reducing risk and uncertainty in carbon offset projects.
More Notes: The study describes a commercial-scale in situ measurement approach, the Direct Measurement Forest Carbon Protocol (DMFCP), using Net Ecosystem Exchange (NEE) and a System-of-Systems (SoS) network for improved accuracy in forest carbon sequestration project determination and Direct Measurement, Reporting, and Verification (DMRV). It aims to address forest carbon market uncertainties by monetizing emission reductions, integrating additional greenhouse gas fluxes (CH4, N2O) and isotopes, and critiques traditional carbon accounting methods and limitations of the Paris Agreement and UNFCCC verification processes. Extrapolation of NEE data is illustrative, and the study acknowledges the importance of long-term CO2 measurement and potential reversals in carbon sequestration due to climate change, assuming 100% product sales covering DMFCP costs; uncertainty in carbon product sales is represented by a ±20% variance.
Adaptation considered: Not directly addressed. Focus is on direct carbon flux measurement protocols (DMFCP) for carbon accounting and revenue generation from forest carbon projects, contrasting with estimation-based protocols. No mention of adaptation strategies or consideration of climate change impacts and how to adapt to them.

Paper Title: Economic damages from Hurricane Sandy attributable to sea level rise caused by anthropogenic climate change
Outcome(s) of Interest: $8.1B (central estimate) Sandy damages attributable to anthropogenic sea level rise; 71,000 additional people affected by flooding.
Drivers of Risk: Climate-mediated anthropogenic sea level rise (ASLR), Hurricane Sandy flood extent/depth, impact on human exposure and property damage.
Methodology: The study quantifies the impact of anthropogenic sea level rise (ASLR) on Hurricane Sandy's damages by simulating water levels and damage under actual conditions and at lower sea levels corresponding to different ASLR estimates. ASLR estimation utilizes budget-based (collating contributions from land-ice melt, ocean thermal expansion, and land-water-storage changes) and semi-empirical approaches (based on global temperature timeseries and CMIP5 climate model simulations, with downscaling to the New York area). Hydrodynamic flood simulations are performed using the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Coastal Storm Modeling System (CSTORM-MS). Damage is calculated based on depth-damage curves for 33 building types, and damages/exposures for specific ASLR amounts are interpolated between simulation results at various water levels.
Highlights: Approximately $8.1B of Hurricane Sandy's damages and flood exposure of 71,000 people are attributable to anthropogenic sea level rise (ASLR); the study uses flood modeling to estimate ASLR's contribution to coastal storm damages and improve cost estimates of climate change, finding significant exposure and damage due to ASLR, including an additional 36,000 housing units affected in the tri-state area, and suggests that ASLR in New York may be lower than globally.
More Notes: The study isolates climate-driven sea level rise from other sea level changes, does not factor in storm track or intensity changes due to climate change, and may underestimate impacts due to unaccounted land subsidence and ocean variability. It assumes a consistent distribution of sea-level components like glaciers and the Greenland ice sheet and minimal ocean dynamics influence near New York compared to global changes. Spatial bias correction is applied for flood modeling accuracy, and simpler proxy methods like flood volume per block are assessed.
Adaptation considered: Adaptation isn't directly modeled. Instead, the study assesses potential damage reduction by simulating flood impacts under lower sea level scenarios, effectively showing what avoided damages *could* have been if sea level rise were less. It interpolates damages for specific amounts of sea level rise between simulated water levels.

Paper Title: Dry spells and global crop production: A multi-stressor and multi-timescale analysis
Outcome(s) of Interest: Depressed growth, aggregate crop production, dry spells, hottest part of the year, multi-stressor interaction.
Drivers of Risk: Dry spells (frequency, duration), heat waves (frequency, duration), drought (SPEI, national levels), aridity (index), temperature (average, annual), precipitation (annual), irrigation (presence/absence), soil moisture, water stress (short-term, medium-term, long-term), extreme weather events, climate extremes.
Methodology: The study employs a global panel data analysis using daily precipitation and temperature spanning 1979 to 2016, with a multi-stressor approach focusing on dry spells, heat waves, drought, and aridity. It utilizes a net crop production index relative to 2014-2016 averages, and employs regression models with fixed effects, clustered standard errors, and sequential g-estimation to isolate and evaluate dry spell impacts. The model operationalizes dry spells based on consecutive abnormally dry days, defines drought using SPEI, and leverages spatial weighting and crop-specific variables to capture regional variations. Methodological robustness is checked via alternative model specifications, lagged variables, and interaction-term regressions.
Highlights: Dry spells during the hottest part of the year negatively impact crop production, especially in non-irrigated areas, with impacts exacerbated by aridity and drought; these effects are modified by heat waves, irrigation, and water deficits, requiring a multi-stressor perspective; findings highlight the importance of adaptation strategies like irrigation and nutrient management to mitigate the impact of punctuated extreme events on agriculture.
More Notes: The study analyzes the impact of dry spells (7-35 days, focusing on 4-5 week spells during hottest periods) and heat waves on aggregate crop production (primarily cereals, weighted by area and production) using a global panel dataset (1979-2016). It considers interactive effects of dry spells, heat waves, drought, and aridity, examining persistence and limitations of irrigation as an adaptation. The analysis uses country-level data and controls to avoid confounding factors, acknowledging limitations of gridded data and potential endogeneity of irrigation. Methodologically, it uses g-estimation with bootstrapping for inference and explores different weighting schemes and model specifications for robustness. The analysis considers varying thresholds for dry spells and heat waves and examines the role of temperature and precipitation as covariates.
Adaptation considered: Irrigation data is incorporated. Reweighting dry spell exposure by average cereal productivity refines the role of irrigation. Sample splits are performed based on country-level drought and aridity, and models are estimated separately for each sub-sample. There is assessment of dry spell effects varying with aridity, drought, or irrigation.

Paper Title: Invasive hematophagous arthropods and associated diseases in a changing world
Outcome(s) of Interest: Vector-borne diseases, invasive arthropods, human health impacts, ecosystem effects, urbanization, climate change, disease mitigation, preventative measures, transboundary surveillance, One Health approach.
Drivers of Risk: Climate change; Urbanization; Urban heat islands; International trade/transport; Socioeconomic factors; Livestock trade; Niche shifts; Light/fertilizer pollution; Insecticide resistance.
Methodology: Modeling efforts should focus on worldwide projections of vector-borne diseases under future climate change, pollution, and urbanization scenarios; laboratory studies assessed survival rates in contaminated vs. uncontaminated waters.
Highlights: Climate change exacerbates the ecological, economic, and health problems associated with invasive hematophagous arthropods and vector-borne diseases by increasing transmission, vector population growth, and range expansion; urbanization and globalization further amplify these risks through microhabitat creation, increased translocation, and the potential for insecticide resistance; strong preventative monitoring, transboundary surveillance, and rapid response are urgently needed, along with political commitment and social-ethnological approaches, to mitigate future invasions and disease outbreaks.
More Notes: Invasive hematophagous arthropods, particularly mosquitoes and ticks, pose a growing threat due to factors like trade in used tires and ornamental plants, urbanization, agricultural practices, climate change, and the transport of vertebrates. Proactive measures like monitoring and citizen science are crucial to reduce epidemiological and ecological risks, while stronger preventative monitoring and transboundary surveillance are urgently needed. The global economic burden of these invasions is underestimated, highlighting the importance of biosecurity control and the need for a One Health approach considering ecological, health, and social perspectives. More research is needed on the impact of global change on invasive species population dynamics and disease epidemiology. Shipping, air traffic, and the Belt and Road Initiative increase connectivity and facilitate the spread of these species.
Adaptation considered: Modeling focuses on projections of vector-borne diseases under different future scenarios. The scenarios include climate change, pollution, and urbanization. Laboratory studies explore survival rates under different water contamination conditions.

Paper Title: The impact of fossil fuel combustion on children's health and the associated losses of human capital
Outcome(s) of Interest: Children's health deterioration; reduced human capital in adulthood; economic costs; lifelong health impacts.
Drivers of Risk: Fossil fuel combustion; climate change; air pollution; extreme temperatures; air pollution (PM, O3, black carbon); aeroallergens; extreme weather events; climate-related droughts; sea-level rise.
Methodology: Review synthesizes existing literature on climate change and air pollution impacts on children's health and human capital development.
Highlights: Fossil fuel combustion and climate change significantly impact lifelong health and human capital, harming children's respiratory and mental health, while early-life impairments lead to adult illness or disability. Adverse birth outcomes contribute to cognitive and non-cognitive deficits. The current underestimation of children's health burdens in assessments necessitates a holistic approach, addressing mental health, neurodevelopment, and long-term human capital impacts.
More Notes: Holistic assessments of impacts on children's health, human capital, and economic costs are needed, with future research prioritizing empirical studies and interdisciplinary efforts to clarify relationships and monetize impacts.
Adaptation considered: The review focuses on climate change and air pollution effects on children's health and human capital, with no apparent consideration of adaptation.

Paper Title: Model-based prediction of the potential geographical distribution of the invasive coconut mite, Aceria guerreronis Keifer (Acari: Eriophyidae) based on MaxEnt
Outcome(s) of Interest: Potential global distribution of Aceria guerreronis, habitat suitability, decrease in suitability from 2040 to 2060.
Drivers of Risk: Climate change, invasive species, global warming, CO2 levels, temperature (seasonality, average, extremes), precipitation (annual, seasonality), drought, SSP1-2.6, SSP5-8.5.
Methodology: MaxEnt (maximum entropy) machine learning algorithm was used to model the potential distribution of *Aceria guerreronis*, using species distribution models (SDMs) and bioclimatic data from WorldClim; spatial filtering (R package spThin) was used to reduce spatial autocorrelation; the Maximum Test Sensitivity Plus Specificity (MTSPS) threshold was used to extract suitable/unsuitable areas; MaxEnt model based on 19 bioclimatic datasets (80% training, 20% testing data), with jackknife tests and response curves to evaluate environmental variable contributions; habitat suitability was predicted based on current distribution and future climate scenarios (SSP1-2.6 and SSP5-5.85), projecting to 2040 and 2060; models were run using all occurrences, occurrences excluding Ghana, and only Ghana occurrences.
Highlights: Highlights: The MaxEnt model predicts habitat suitability for the coconut mite, *Aceria guerreronis*, expanding beyond its current distribution to Oceania, Asia, Africa, and the Americas; this expansion is influenced by temperature seasonality, annual average temperature, and annual precipitation, with major coconut-producing countries remaining suitable under SSP2.6, though suitability may decrease under SSP8.5 from 2040 to 2060; these findings inform quarantine measures and policy formulation.
More Notes: The coconut mite *Aceria guerreronis*, a destructive pest, has potential habitat suitability predicted in Oceania, Asia, Africa, and the Americas, though this suitability is expected to decrease from 2040 to 2060. Key factors influencing its distribution include an annual average temperature around 25°C, mean annual precipitation of approximately 1459 mm, and specific levels of precipitation and temperature seasonality; the model's predictions align with historical records but do not account for host plant distribution, anthropogenic activities, or geographic barriers.
Adaptation considered: The paper focuses on species distribution modeling (SDM) using MaxEnt to project habitat suitability under different climate scenarios (SSP2.6 and SSP8.5). While SDMs can inform adaptation strategies, the provided notes primarily describe the modeling process itself (data inputs, model validation, variable importance), not the explicit consideration or evaluation of adaptation actions. The modeling helps understand potential range shifts under climate change, which is a first step for informing adaptation.

Paper Title: Changes in Extreme Daily Precipitation over the Contiguous United States from Convection-Permitting Simulations
Outcome(s) of Interest: Increased extreme precipitation (Dec-May) in Midwest/Ohio Valley; Decreased extreme precipitation (Dec-Feb) in southern Great Plains; Increased variability in precipitation extremes across CONUS cities; Increased return period precipitation amounts for most cities examined.
Drivers of Risk: Anthropogenic climate change, emissions scenarios (RCP4.5/8.5, EOC4.5/8.5), extreme precipitation changes (intensity, frequency, variability), 99th percentile daily precipitation, increased return period precipitation, spatiotemporal patterns, MCS precipitation.
Methodology: Dynamically downscaled convection-permitting WRF-ARW model (3.75 km grid spacing) using bias-corrected CESM GCM output and spectral nudging simulated daily precipitation, defining extremes as the 99th percentile of 24-h accumulated value; Historical (HIST; 1990-2005) data was compared to end-of-century (EOC; 2085-2100) scenarios RCP4.5 (EOC4.5) and RCP8.5 (EOC8.5); Analysis included extreme value theory (block maxima, peak over threshold), Mann-Whitney U test (alpha = 0.1 or p<0.05), RMSE, Pearson's r correlation, Q-Q plots, PDFs, return periods, and a 1000-iteration bootstrap to calculate 95% confidence intervals, focusing on eight climatologically unique cities; Model performance was evaluated using r, p, RMSE, and R2.
Highlights: Dynamically downscaled climate model projects robust increases in extreme daily rainfall in the Midwest and Ohio Valley during some seasons, and decreases in the southern Great Plains. The model also shows a notable increase in the variability of extreme daily precipitation across various CONUS cities by the end of the twenty-first century, with a potential for increased variability and a higher ceiling for precipitation extremes. Extreme value analysis reveals increasing return period precipitation amounts for most cities examined, with some showing increases of 20% or greater for the 100-yr return period. While the model generally performs reasonably, it tends to underestimate the highest magnitude precipitation values and shows regional biases, including wetter conditions in the Intermountain West. Specific regions like the Intermountain West, Southwest, and Northeast also experience statistically significant increases in extreme precipitation. Nationally, 100-year return period precipitation values display an increasing trend.
More Notes: The analysis uses regridding/clipping; hatched areas indicate statistical significance. PRISM data limitations exist as ground truth, and HIST exhibits a dry bias in some regions. Spatial distributions of HIST (SON), Δ EOC4.5 - HIST, Δ EOC8.5 - HIST, % Difference EOC4.5 - HIST, and % Difference EOC8.5 - HIST are presented, with underestimation biases for cities (e.g., Albany, Seattle) in EOC8.5. Figure 8 analyzes eight cities (names not given), showing return periods (5-500 years) with bootstrap medians, means, and 95% confidence intervals. RCMs resolve extreme precipitation by representing smaller-scale convective weather. Stinnett (2023) is directly relevant, focusing on extreme daily precipitation over the CONUS using convection-permitting simulations.
Adaptation considered: Adaptation consideration is not directly mentioned in the paper. The focus is on analyzing historical and projected future extreme precipitation events using convection-permitting climate models. The paper assesses potential changes in these events under different emissions scenarios, which can inform adaptation strategies indirectly by providing detailed insights into future climate risks. However, explicit discussion or evaluation of adaptation measures is absent.

Paper Title: Cost-Benefit Analysis and the environment: The time horizon is of the essence
Outcome(s) of Interest: Accurate welfare evaluation; Avoidance of bias towards carbon-intensive/environmentally damaging projects; Promotion of sustainable development.
Drivers of Risk: Long-term environmental costs & benefits; Carbon-intensive projects; Greenhouse gas emissions; Climate change impacts; Ecosystem damages; Energy & transport projects; Waste decomposition.
Methodology: The methodology discussed is Cost-Benefit Analysis (CBA) with emphasis on the importance of the time horizon, incorporating sustainability, ecosystem services valuation, equity considerations, the 'Total Economic Value' (TEV) approach, scenario approaches, sensitivity analysis, declining discount rates, and quantifying the impact of different time horizons and discount rates on benefit flows.
Highlights: Long time horizons (100+ years) are crucial in CBA for projects with long-term environmental impacts (climate change, ecosystem damages) to capture welfare gains/losses and avoid biases towards carbon-intensive/damaging projects; this impact is often greater than that of discount rates; sustainability, ecosystem services, equity, and planetary boundaries must be integrated; mainstreaming sustainability into government is needed; shorter time horizons can introduce optimism or pessimism bias.
More Notes: Longer time horizons (100+ years) are advocated for cost-benefit analyses (CBA) of environmental impacts, similar to infrastructure lifetimes, and should be considered early in project scoping; the choice of time horizon significantly affects appraisal results; environmental externalities to GDP per capita growth can inform unit prices; uncertainty in long-term analysis is a challenge.
Adaptation considered: CBA is the methodology discussed. Time horizon, scenario planning for uncertainty, discount rates, and sensitivity analysis within CBA are key elements reviewed. The paper also highlights sustainability, ecosystem services valuation, and equity considerations within CBA.

Paper Title: Housing market dynamics of the post-Sandy Hudson estuary, Long Island Sound, and New Jersey coastline are explained by NFIP participation
Outcome(s) of Interest: Long-term decline in home values after initial impact buffered by NFIP.
Drivers of Risk: Flooding (all types), Hurricane Sandy, flood insurance (NFIP), community risk perception.
Methodology: A socio-environmental model, incorporating community perceptions, housing prices, population density, and flood awareness, is employed alongside an interrupted time series model, sigmoid recovery, and K-shaped recovery models to evaluate the impact of flooding on housing prices across 496 coastal census tracts in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut, using data from 1970 to 2021 for calibration and employing Spearman's ranked correlation to explore relationships between model parameters and factors like NFIP participation and flood preparedness.
Highlights: The study highlights that while the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) absorbed the initial economic impact of Hurricane Sandy, long-term declines in housing values were driven by perceived risk rather than actual flood hazards, with regional variations in perception further influencing market dynamics and insurance participation impacting housing value stability.
More Notes: The study reveals that New York, Connecticut, and New Jersey coastal census tracts with larger changes in active flood insurance policies post-flood show greater declines in home values, despite a steady increase in housing prices from 1970 to 2012, which was occasionally slowed by minor floods, highlighting the complex relationship between flood risk, insurance, and community perceptions.
Adaptation considered: The paper employs a socio-environmental (SE) model to incorporate community perceptions, flood awareness, NFIP participation, and preparedness in assessing flood impacts and housing market responses to climate hazards in coastal census tracts. The models incorporate precipitation, storm surge, economic losses, and population density. Time-varying housing price models (Sigmoid, ITS, K-shaped) are used to evaluate and simulate housing price impacts and recovery.

Paper Title: Vegetation fires in the Anthropocene
Outcome(s) of Interest: Economic losses; air pollution; human mortality; environmental damage; greenhouse gas emissions.
Drivers of Risk: Climate change, drought, high temperatures, altered precipitation, fuel dryness, vegetation changes (land-use/cover, invasive species, deforestation), anthropogenic factors (ignitions, suppression, logging), fire weather index, WUI expansion, fossil fuel emissions, El Niño-Southern Oscillation, human activity, socio-economic factors.
Methodology: The review uses satellite observations (including MODIS burned area data), ERA5, MTBS data, historical reconstructions, regional analyses, process-based Earth System Models, and statistical environmental-niche modeling to analyze fire trends, emissions, and future fire regimes; it also incorporates Fire Weather Index calculations from climate models and emphasizes the importance of monitoring, fire regime quantification based on climate, terrain, and vegetation, identifying fire causes, and utilizing the Global Fire Atlas.
Highlights: Fire regimes are changing globally due to climate change, human activities, and complex interactions, leading to increased fire frequency, severity, and area burned in many regions, particularly in flammable forests, boreal zones, and tropical rainforests; this can cause significant economic losses, air pollution, greenhouse gas emissions, and landscape transformations, requiring effective fire stewardship incorporating indigenous knowledge, transdisciplinary research, and consideration of both climate and non-climate factors to mitigate risks and adapt to changing fire regimes in the Anthropocene.
More Notes: Fire activity detection and prediction is challenging due to short records, regional variability, and human influence; regional-scale analyses are crucial; area burned alone is insufficient to assess economic risk; adaptation and effective fire regime management are vital for sustainability and emission reduction; fuel management requires frequent application and large-scale treatment; managed fire can have negative socio-ecological side effects; boreal fire reduction demands a multi-pronged, international approach; increased investment in training, capacity building, and diversity in fire management is needed.
Adaptation considered: Adaptation and management approaches need tailoring to specific contexts (environmental and socio-ecological). Transdisciplinary, applied research co-designed with communities and agencies is emphasized. Careful monitoring and evaluation of managed fire regimes are required.

Paper Title: Anthropogenic Warming and Population Growth May Double US Heat Stress by the Late 21st Century
Outcome(s) of Interest: Increased potential impact of short-to-medium duration heat stress events; disproportionate impact on densely populated regions (Northeast, Southeast Piedmont, Midwest, Desert Southwest); climate change significantly amplifies impact in Pacific Northwest, California, and Great Lakes region.
Drivers of Risk: Anthropogenic warming, population growth/exposure, extreme temperature/humidity, greenhouse gas emissions, climate scenarios (RCP4.5, RCP8.5), changes in temperature distribution (variance, higher-order moments), heat event duration (1-7 days).
Category: Health > Heat and Cold (Cardiovascular, Respiratory, etc.)
Methodology: The study uses the IPCC risk framework to assess heat stress (HS) impact across CONUS, employing observations, CMIP5 climate projections, and population estimates. The methodology includes non-stationary frequency analysis using Generalized Extreme Value (GEV) models applied to annual maxima of summer heat index (AM-HI) to estimate 40-year heat index (40YHI) under various climate scenarios (RCP4.5, RCP8.5) and time periods (historical, near-future, far-future). Heat index (HI) is calculated from temperature and humidity data, bias-corrected, and regridded to a 2° spatial resolution. Population data is used from 2000-2020, interpolated to annual estimates, and aggregated to the same resolution. Potential impact (PI) is estimated by combining population exposure with HS characteristics for 1, 3, and 7-day durations, using an indicator-based assessment technique with a geometric aggregation of normalized variables and equal weights to calculate a composite indicator. Changes in HS exposure are investigated using a Relative Risk (RR) framework, considering climate change and population changes separately and in interaction, using model-ensemble averages from 9 CMIP5 GCMs. The analysis examines spatial patterns of decadal trends in WTS and explores different climate projection models/scenarios (e.g., SSP2, SSP5), analyzing total, climate change, population, and interaction effects on HS using gridded mean population estimates.
Highlights: Projected heat stress severity in the contiguous U.S. is set to double by 2060-2099, with the greatest risks in the Pacific Northwest, central California, and the Great Lakes; increasing population exposure significantly influences these risks, with a notable rise in severe heat events across various regions, especially under high emissions scenarios like RCP8.5.
More Notes: Focuses on 1-7 day heat stress events, employing a decomposition approach to assess climate and population impacts on health risks, using Block Maxima method on yearly summer Heat Index (HI) maxima under SSP2 and SSP5 scenarios; GEV model scale parameter uses exponential function for positivity; indicators are min-max normalized; analysis covers n=3 indicators, S=5 climate scenarios, and m=210 CONUS grid locations; heat stress trends differ from temperature trends in the Midwest and South; Great Lakes region faces acclimation/adaptation challenges; study presents projected heat stress indices spatially; and highlights the importance of demographic and socioeconomic factors for adaptation.
Adaptation considered: No explicit adaptation strategies or measures are considered. The study focuses on assessing risk by analyzing vulnerability, potential impact, and (implicitly) adaptive capacity as components of risk, using population projections and climate scenarios. It quantifies changes in heat stress exposure using a Relative Risk (RR) framework, factoring in climate and population changes.

Paper Title: Comparison of sustainable flood risk management by four countries - the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, the United States, and Japan - and the implications for Asian coastal megacities
Outcome(s) of Interest: Long-term sustainable flood risk management; integration of social, economic, and environmental considerations in FRM; lessons for coastal megacities; moving towards sustainability in flood management policies.
Drivers of Risk: Climate change (sea-level rise, storm intensity/frequency, extreme precipitation), urbanization/land-use change, rapid socio-economic growth, population density, subsidence (groundwater extraction), inadequate infrastructure/flood defenses, loss of wetland storage, expansion of impermeable surfaces, typhoons, storm surges, natural factors.
Methodology: Review of flood management experiences in four developed countries (UK, Netherlands, USA, Japan) via literature review, policy analysis (e.g., NPPF, River Law), and case study comparison; includes analysis of flood management policy evolution over time and comparison of satellite images to illustrate flooding extent.
Highlights: Highlights: Integrating social, ecological, and economic themes into flood risk management (FRM) is crucial for long-term sustainability, requiring mixed options; the US, UK, Netherlands, and Japan are integrating sustainability into flood management, with the US facing challenges despite a mixed-options approach; Japan emphasizes public engagement, awareness, and climate projections; Asian cities are transitioning from hard-engineering to incorporating socio-economic factors, early warning systems, and climate change adaptation due to the unsustainability of traditional defenses.
More Notes: The paper analyzes SFRM's evolution and contrasts different country approaches, highlighting US floodplain recommendations and Japan's climate-integrative resilience strategy, emphasizing the need for sustainable, mixed-option flood risk management in vulnerable Asian megacities under climate change, with a focus on non-structural, socio-environmental considerations.
Adaptation considered: Flood management strategies are evolving towards sustainable flood risk management (SFRM). Strategies include restricting development in high-risk flood areas, strategic flood risk assessments by local authorities, relocation, setback strategies, and integrating social and environmental considerations. Future climate projections inform fluvial flood prediction. Focus is shifting from flood protection to broader risk management approaches.

Paper Title: Creeping disaster along the US coastline: Understanding exposure to sea level rise and hurricanes through historical development
Outcome(s) of Interest: Increased property loss risk, uneven distribution across cities, faster development in SLR zones, density convergence in less-developed coastal areas, adaptation policies increasingly important.
Drivers of Risk: Sea level rise, hurricanes, exposure, coastal hazards, urban development, NOAA zones, high risk, flooding, wind speed, storm hits, low elevation, southern Florida.
Methodology: The study analyzes historical building patterns in U.S. coastal areas (1900-2015) using the HISDAC-US dataset, derived from Zillow's ZTRAX database, at a 50-meter resolution, combined with NOAA sea level rise (SLR) zones. Metropolitan Statistical Areas (MSAs) are used as the unit of analysis, intersected with hurricane landfall data (HURDAT2). Protected areas and wetlands are excluded from SLR zones. Zonal statistics are used to calculate structures within SLR zones. Expansion and densification are quantified over 10-year increments using buildings per unit area (BUPR). Panel regression models with fixed effects are employed to assess the relationship between hurricane activity and building patterns inside and outside SLR zones, using dependent variables like built-up land share, structure density, and total structures, and independent variables like wind speed and hurricane hits, adjusted by census division fixed effects.
Highlights: SLR zones developed faster with higher structure density than non-coastal areas, especially in hurricane-prone regions; coastal zones experienced high expansion and densification; flood zones show significant growth; coastlines are more developed than inland areas, but relative exposure decreased except for the South Atlantic, while absolute exposure increased; MSAs affected by hurricanes are denser; SLR zones are more built up; storm activity is associated with denser urban landscapes; coastal regions are converging in density, increasing exposure; expansion is transitioning to densification; development trends may constrain future adaptation efforts; older structures indicate elevated vulnerability; coastal areas continue to grow despite hazards, stressing the need for adaptive building codes.
More Notes: Coastal development is expanding and densifying in SLR zones and hurricane-prone areas, particularly in the Western Gulf coast, with older Northeast areas already highly dense; saturation effects suggest adaptation policies should prioritize existing buildings, considering socio-economic factors, as building condition and adaptation impact vulnerability, though data limitations exist; hurricane activity tends to concentrate building patterns.
Adaptation considered: Examines historical settlement patterns in sea level rise (SLR) zones, using data from 1900 to 2015, to quantify exposure and assess development trends. Analyzes settlement expansion and densification in areas at risk from SLR and hurricanes, distinguishing development trends inside and outside 6-foot SLR zones. Regression models investigate the impact of hurricane activity on coastal building patterns, with results providing insights into historical development and potential future exposure risks. Vulnerability is assessed through patterns of urban expansion and building ages, highlighting patterns that influence adaptive capacity.

Paper Title: Mortality attributable to PM2.5 from wildland fires in California from 2008 to 2018
Outcome(s) of Interest: Premature deaths attributable to wildfire PM2.5; economic impact.
Drivers of Risk: Wildfire PM2.5, air pollution (PM2.5, nitrogen dioxide, ozone).
Methodology: The study quantified premature mortality (2008-2018) in California due to wildfire-attributable PM2.5 using the CMAQ modeling system (versions 5.0.1 to 5.3; 12-km resolution) to estimate fire-only PM2.5 concentrations, ZIP code-level mortality data from CDPH, and a calculated chronic, wildfire-specific PM2.5 dose-response coefficient (βWL). Two exposure scenarios (base case and modified cap, with concentrations capped at the 99.9th percentile) were used. Mortality burden was calculated using a dose-response function that considered the change in PM2.5 concentration from wildland fire smoke and total deaths in adults ages 25 and up. Economic valuation was performed by multiplying the mortality burden by the VSL, accounting for income growth to the year 2015. Uncertainties were addressed via a Monte Carlo distribution for the dose-response value and use of a 'mod cap' scenario.
Highlights: Wildfire smoke exposure in California from 2008-2018 is linked to substantial mortality and economic burdens, exceeding previous estimates, with wildfire-related PM2.5 accounting for a significant portion of total PM2.5-attributable deaths; later years (2017, 2018) saw higher mortality due to fires expanding to more populated areas; wildfire PM2.5 may be more toxic than other PM2.5 sources; the study uses a wildfire-specific dose-response coefficient to estimate chronic mortality impacts, emphasizing the need for community resilience and protection of vulnerable populations.
More Notes: Study quantifies mortality burden from California wildfire PM2.5 (2008-2018) using high-resolution mortality data, wildfire-specific dose-response, and 12-km gridded PM2.5 estimates; wildfire-specific dose-response yields ~35% higher mortality than undifferentiated PM2.5 response; impacts are widespread due to smoke transport (see supplemental materials); higher concentrations primarily occur during severe fire events; mortality calculations were replicated with undifferentiated PM2.5 dose-response, and supplemental analyses used alternative short-term wildfire PM2.5 dose-response values; funding sources suggest a California and US-wide focus.
Adaptation considered: Adaptation is not explicitly considered in this study. The focus is on quantifying mortality burden from wildfire PM2.5 exposure using modeling and dose-response relationships, with some consideration of uncertainty through capping PM2.5 values.

Paper Title: The potential for coral reef restoration to mitigate coastal flooding as sea levels rise
Outcome(s) of Interest: Mitigation of coastal flooding; Reversal of reef erosion; Reefs keeping pace with ~0.5m sea-level rise (moderate emissions); Preservation of coral-reef ecosystem services.
Drivers of Risk: Coral-reef degradation, sea-level rise, storms, bioerosion, thermal stress, SCTLD, extreme weather, bathymetry changes, erosion, carbonate production, climate change.
Methodology: The study combines coral-growth measurements, carbonate-budget assessments (using ReefBudget v1 methodology, linear mixed-effects models, ANOSIM, SIMPER, and matrix models), and hydrodynamic modeling (XBeach) to project future coastal flooding under various sea-level rise, storm, and coral restoration scenarios at Buck Island Reef. Carbonate budgets from 54 sites assess reef accretion/erosion dynamics, considering bioerosion. Coral-growth experiments and a population model project coral cover and accretion rates. The model was validated against observed wave data.
Highlights: Successful restoration of Acropora palmata can mitigate extreme coastal flooding impacts by enhancing reef-accretion potential, counteracting sea-level rise, maintaining coral cover, and lowering wave-driven water levels, particularly when restoration efforts begin before 2030 and are coupled with additional management actions and climate-change mitigation.
More Notes: Coral restoration at Buck Island Reef (U.S. Virgin Islands) could mitigate coastal flooding by reversing reef erosion and enabling reefs to keep pace with ~0.5m sea-level rise by 2100 under moderate emissions reductions, but success depends on coral growth, reef accretion, and resilience, with optimistic scenarios projecting >10% coral cover increase by 2100; high parrotfish bioerosion and physical erosion from storms and SCTLD pose challenges, suggesting present-day reef accretion estimates may be overly optimistic, and acknowledges uncertainties regarding restoration success, assuming isometric growth of Acropora palmata and using reef-crest habitat area for percent cover calculations.
Adaptation considered: Coral restoration scenarios are modeled to project reef accretion potential and its impact on coastal flooding. These scenarios are incorporated into carbonate-budget and coral-growth models to project reef elevation changes and total water levels under various sea-level rise and storm conditions. Bioerosion rates are also considered.

Paper Title: Ancient Sea Level as Key to the Future
Outcome(s) of Interest: Past warm periods demonstrate potential for significant sea level rise with elevated CO2 levels, and future emissions scenarios project substantial sea level rise with potential for multi-meter increases this century.
Drivers of Risk: Sea level rise; ice volume changes; CO2 concentrations; tectonic processes; ocean temperature; land ice volume; ocean basin volume; ice sheet growth/decay; orbital cycles; volcanic activity; anthropogenic warming; ocean warming; ice sheet/glacier melt.
Methodology: Ancient sea level reconstructions utilize proxies (e.g., benthic foraminiferal δ18O), radiometric data, sea level curves, drilling data, sequence stratigraphy, and backstripping (accounting for compaction, loading, and thermal subsidence); data analysis includes statistical methods, smoothing techniques (e.g., Gaussian convolution filters), and process modeling, while modern sea level changes are measured using tide gauges and satellite data.
Highlights: GMSL has historically been influenced by ice volume changes with significant impacts from anthropogenic CO2; ancient analogs predict a ~10 m long-term rise under moderate emissions, with a >2 m rise possible this century under high emissions; small ice sheets existed in Antarctica during warm periods, and significant Pliocene warming saw 22±10 m higher sea levels; modern GMSL rise began in the late 19th century with the current rate being the fastest in 3,000 years, indicating ongoing GMSL acceleration.
More Notes: Sea level is used as a climate indicator; regional sea level is affected by land motion and thermal subsidence. The paper discusses Hothouse, Icehouse, and Greenhouse climate states in their historical context. The sea level record older than 48 million years has uncertainties; New Jersey estimates for the Early to Middle Eocene were adjusted to compensate for long-term effects.
Adaptation considered: Adaptation is not explicitly considered in these notes. The focus is on measuring, reconstructing, and projecting sea level changes using various data sources, modeling techniques, and statistical analyses.

Paper Title: Disentangling the drivers of future Antarctic ice loss with a historically calibrated ice-sheet model
Outcome(s) of Interest: Antarctic ice sheet mass loss; sea-level rise (SLR); ocean-driven loss in West Antarctica (near-term); atmosphere-driven loss (long-term, high emissions); critical warming threshold (+7.5°C); West Antarctic ice sheet collapse (high emissions); grounding-line retreat in East Antarctica (high emissions); SLR by 2100: 6 (-8 to 15) cm (low emissions), 5.5 (-10 to 16) cm (high emissions); SLR by 2300/3000: 0.62/1.85 m (low emissions), 2.75/6.95 m (high emissions); Thwaites Glacier retreat (all scenarios).
Drivers of Risk: Ocean warming (sub-shelf melt, CDW), atmospheric warming (surface runoff, SMB decrease), melt-elevation feedback, ice discharge, ice-ocean/ice-atmosphere interactions, hydrofracturing, calving, Thwaites Glacier retreat, high-emission pathways (SSP5-8.5), uncertainties in climate forcing and ice sheet parameters.
Methodology: An ensemble of simulations using the Kori-ULB ice-sheet model, observationally calibrated against historical mass balance estimates (IMBIE), employs CMIP6 climate models for forcing, utilizing SSP1-2.6 and SSP5-8.5 scenarios. Starting from 1950, simulations incorporate inverse simulation for initial conditions, a perturbed parameter ensemble, Bayesian calibration, and account for uncertainties in ice-ocean-atmosphere boundary processes. A PDD-based scheme calculates surface mass balance, while PICO and plume models estimate sub-shelf melt rates. The analysis distinguishes atmospheric and oceanic forcings' separate impacts and uses uncertainty analysis through Latin hypercube sampling.
Highlights: Ocean warming is identified as the primary driver of short-term mass loss in Antarctica, with atmospheric warming shifting from mitigation through snowfall to amplifying mass loss through increased surface runoff under very high-emissions scenarios, potentially leading to a collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet. Projections highlight significant uncertainties in ice-sheet evolution driven by interactions between oceanic and atmospheric forces, with the Antarctic contribution to global mean sea-level rise depending heavily on future emissions paths, showing potentially substantial divergence beyond the 21st century.
More Notes: The study uses the Kori-ULB ice-sheet model, calibrated with CMIP5 data but forced by CMIP6 climate models, to project Antarctic ice sheet changes. The model employs multiple sub-shelf melt parameterizations and explores uncertainties in ice-ocean and ice-atmosphere interactions. Mass loss is primarily driven by oceanic forcing, particularly in the Amundsen Sea Embayment, with continued Thwaites Glacier retreat predicted even under present-day conditions. Under a very high emission scenario (SSP5-8.5, acknowledged as unlikely on multi-century timescales), a critical warming threshold leads to increased surface runoff and accelerated mass loss, potentially resulting in West Antarctic ice sheet collapse. The model has limitations including coarse resolution, absence of a water-routing scheme, omission of the melt-albedo feedback, and computational constraints leading to the use of a standalone ice-sheet model with independent atmospheric and oceanic boundary conditions. The Kori-ULB model's behavior is validated against high-resolution models. The code and datasets are publicly available.
Adaptation considered: Adaptation not directly considered. Focus is on modeling and projecting ice sheet evolution under different emission scenarios (SSP1-2.6 and SSP5-8.5) using various ice sheet models (Kori-ULB, f.ETISh), CMIP5 and CMIP6 climate models, and observational data (IMBIE, IMBIE2), with uncertainty quantification through Bayesian calibration and ensemble simulations. Melt parameterizations and hydrofracturing are included in some simulations.

Paper Title: Future redistribution of fishery resources suggests biological and economic trade-offs according to the severity of the emission scenario
Outcome(s) of Interest: Changes in species abundance & distribution; Winners/losers under climate change; Declining catches near major port (Dutch Harbor) under SSP585; Economic impacts on commercial & subsistence fisheries; Implications for transboundary resource management.
Drivers of Risk: Climate change, warming, sea ice concentration/loss, net primary production, SSPs, species abundance/distribution shifts.
Methodology: The study projects future changes in the abundance and distribution of eight commercially important fish and crab species in the eastern Bering and Chukchi Seas (2021-2100) under different CMIP6 SSPs, using a bioeconomic modeling approach that integrates climate and ocean productivity projections with machine learning algorithms (Random Forest and Boosted Regression Trees) to predict species abundance based on climate layers (including bottom temperatures), summer net primary production (SNPP), and bathymetry, trained using trawl survey data (2000-2019); Ensemble model predictions are used to estimate maximum sustainable yield (MSY), maximum catch potential (MCP), maximum revenue potential (MRP), and maximum profit potential (MPP), considering species-specific population growth rates and assuming constant prices and costs; the analysis also examines shifts in the center of gravity of species abundance and overlaps present-day fishing grounds with aggregated fishing effort data (2012-2020).
Highlights: Projected abundance and distribution shifts in commercially important species in the eastern Bering and Chukchi Seas vary across climate scenarios (CMIP6 SSPs). The least changes occur under SSP126, while SSP585 leads to abundance increases for Pacific cod and decreases for snow crab, with corresponding shifts in their centers of gravity. Catches near Dutch Harbor may decline for valuable fisheries under SSP585 due to catch composition changes. Shifts in species distribution are minimal under SSP126 and significant under SSP370 and SSP585. Abundance declines are observed in the EBS for abundant cod and flatfish taxa, with increases in the Chukchi Sea, and opposite patterns for low vs. high economic value species. Maximum catch potential (MCP) increases in the Chukchi Sea are driven by low-value taxa. Economic impacts (MRP, MPP) are most significant late-century under SSP585. Increases in MCP do not necessarily translate to increases in MRP and MPP. High greenhouse gas emissions (SSP585) can lead to economic impacts, potentially from the loss of high-value taxa. Redistribution of fishery resources could lead to governance and management issues, fisheries conflicts, overexploitation risks, ecological shifts, and altered predator-prey dynamics. Limited economic impact is expected in well-managed ecosystems under low to moderate climatic changes in the near-term (2021–2040), but mitigation strategies are needed as climate change intensifies.
More Notes: Study projects abundance and distribution changes in the eastern Bering and Chukchi Seas under different SSPs (including extreme SSP585), highlighting potential impacts on commercial/subsistence fisheries, trans-boundary resource management, and fishing fleet mobility, while acknowledging limitations from simplified biological/economic assumptions, limited species subset, and machine learning models.
Adaptation considered: Adaptation is not explicitly modeled. Biological parameters, prices, and costs are assumed constant across present and future periods. Sensitivity analyses explore changing costs and prices, but active adaptation strategies are not included.

Paper Title: Population at risk of dengue virus transmission has increased due to coupled climate factors and population growth
Outcome(s) of Interest: Increased dengue transmission suitability; expanded geographic distribution of suitable areas; increased population in high-suitability areas.
Drivers of Risk: Climate change (temperature, humidity), population growth, urbanization.
Methodology: The study quantifies climate suitability for dengue transmission using Index P, a measure based on mechanistic models incorporating temperature and relative humidity data from 1979-2022, and compares climate suitability (using a threshold of 0.5) and associated population changes between 1979-1983 and 2017/2018-2022; it also employs censored linear regression, random-effects models, a Tobit model, and the seasonal Mann-Kendall test with Sen's slope (with prewhitening) to relate climate suitability to observed dengue incidence.
Highlights: Expansion of climate suitability for dengue in North America, East Asia, and the Mediterranean basin is occurring, while high suitability remains concentrated in the tropics; temperate zones saw the largest increase in high climate suitability, contributing to a greater incidence of dengue.
More Notes: The analysis utilizes publicly available data, such as climate-based transmission suitability, global population counts, and dengue cases, processed with R software. It highlights dengue case under-reporting in regions like Central and Eastern Africa, suggesting climate suitability indicates potential epidemic activity over endemic transmission. Expansion in high-suitability areas due to population growth is noted in the Global South, while the Global North saw expansions in suitable land area despite various population growth levels.
Adaptation considered: Adaptation is not explicitly considered. The paper focuses on modeling and analyzing historical and current climate suitability for dengue transmission and its relationship to observed dengue incidence, without incorporating any adaptive measures.

Paper Title: Population at risk of dengue virus transmission has increased due to coupled climate factors and population growth
Outcome(s) of Interest: Expansion of climate suitability for dengue transmission; increased population in high-suitability areas; increased dengue transmission risk, particularly in the Global South.
Drivers of Risk: Climate change, urbanization, population growth, temperature, humidity, historical suitability.
Methodology: The study employed mechanistic models to determine geographical limits of dengue transmission using Index P, which assesses climate suitability based on historical satellite temperature and humidity data from 1979-2022, comparing climate suitability between two periods (1979-1983 and 2018-2022). The analysis involved censored linear regression, random-effects models, and Tobit models for select countries, and utilized a seasonal Mann-Kendall test with Sen's slope to evaluate trends, incorporating prewhitening to address autocorrelation.
Highlights: Climate suitability for dengue transmission is expanding in North America, East Asia, and the Mediterranean basin, with the largest increases in temperate zones, while historically high-suitability tropical zones saw smaller increases; this, coupled with population growth, particularly in the Global South, is increasing the risk of dengue transmission in both endemic and previously disease-free areas.
More Notes: Dengue study acknowledges under-reporting in some regions; highlights Global South population growth in high-suitability areas and Global North expansion of high-suitability land area; utilizes publicly available climate, population, and case data, analyzed using R.
Adaptation considered: Adaptation is not explicitly considered in this study. The analysis focuses on quantifying changes in climate suitability for dengue transmission based on temperature and humidity, comparing historical and recent periods (1979-1983 vs. 2017-2022 or 2018-2022), and relating this suitability to observed dengue incidence. It does not model or incorporate any adaptive behaviors or interventions.

Paper Title: Which Investors Matter for Equity Valuations and Expected Returns?
Outcome(s) of Interest: Equity price impacts, wealth distribution shifts (gains for passive investors, losses for active investors).
Drivers of Risk: Climate-related risks, environmental scores, stakeholder preferences (demand for green firms), regulatory risk, physical damages, carbon tax policies, carbon tail risk.
Methodology: The study employs an asset demand system and valuation regressions using quarterly U.S. data from 2000-2019. Key methodologies include: re-estimating valuation regressions with counterfactual prices, an instrumental variables shrinkage estimator, GMM with a ridge penalty, a two-step estimation of investors' demand, instrumental variables to address endogeneity, analysis of investor characteristics impacting firm demand, an algorithm to solve for market-clearing prices, reallocation of assets across investor groups to assess repricing, a valuation model to link valuations to expected returns, decomposition of active share, regression analysis on firm valuations and characteristics, construction of climate-related risk counterfactuals, modeling the impact of a carbon tax, and a ridge-IV estimator for the demand curve, using data from CRSP, Compustat, and FactSet, Sustainalytics.
Highlights: Climate-induced shifts in asset demand can significantly impact equity prices and wealth distribution, benefiting passive investment advisors, pension funds, insurance companies, and private banking while potentially causing capital losses for active investment advisors and hedge funds; foreign investors help lower the cost of capital for green firms in the US and tilt their portfolios towards greener firms, while small-active investment advisors and hedge funds have the largest impact on prices and the pricing of the environmental index and governance in US markets; the trend from active to passive management makes firm characteristics increasingly important in explaining valuation ratios, and reactivating investors shifts coefficients on environmental and governance characteristics closer to zero; institutional investors are key in affecting the market valuation of climate risks, and different investor types have different sensitivities to repricing, with hedge funds exhibiting the highest and large passive investors the lowest.
More Notes: The study uses an asset demand system to quantify the impact of market trends and regulation changes on asset prices, informativeness, and wealth distribution, focusing on the shift from active to passive investing and climate-induced asset demand shifts; it utilizes ESG measures (Sustainalytics environmental score, Bebchuk et al. entrenchment index), analyzes investor demand heterogeneity, and models asset pricing incorporating investor preferences and risk factors; while it doesn't directly assess physical climate impacts, it explores transition risk related to demand for "green" firms and how climate risks are incorporated into asset prices by different investor groups, analyzing 'Total Repricing' by investor type using metrics like Share AUM and Repricing AUM scaled.
Adaptation considered: The paper models the impact of climate-related risks (regulatory, stakeholder, physical damages, and carbon tax) on firm valuations and investor welfare. It uses counterfactual scenarios, stress tests, and regression analysis to assess these impacts and analyzes how changes in ESG considerations impact company valuations.

Paper Title: Policy and market forces delay real estate price declines on the US coast
Outcome(s) of Interest: Delayed, but not prevented, declines in coastal property values; potential for coastal gentrification.
Drivers of Risk: Sea-level rise (SLR), storms, erosion, inundation, beach nourishment (subsidy reduction), shoreline retreat.
Methodology: The study utilizes the Coastal Home Ownership Model (C-HOM), a coupled human-natural systems, agent-based model simulating a coastal community over a 150-year time horizon to analyze coastal real estate markets. C-HOM incorporates coastal amenities, hazards, policies, beach erosion dynamics, public finance decisions, storm risk, and real estate markets in other locations, considering heterogeneity in risk preferences. The model uses a user cost of housing framework to determine rent and price bids, and agents (homeowners and investors) vote on beach nourishment plans based on cost-benefit analysis. Simulations include baseline scenarios with subsidized beach nourishment and variations exploring reduced subsidies, appreciating outside markets, and declining outside markets, focusing on the impact of sea-level rise (SLR) on property values.
Highlights: Coastal property values are temporarily supported by subsidies for coastal management (e.g., beach nourishment), tax advantages for high-income owners, and rising property values outside coastal zones, delaying but not preventing eventual declines from sea-level rise (SLR). Removing these subsidies would allow prices to reflect true SLR risks, potentially accelerating coastal gentrification as wealthier individuals enter the market. Long-term, subsidies may be maladaptive, creating real estate bubbles and delaying necessary market adjustments and demographic shifts. SLR initially causes modest property value declines, becoming substantial over decades; high-income influx can temporarily offset this, while declining outside markets exacerbate the impact. Investor market share decreases as property values decline. Beach width decreases and income tax rates for owners increase. Adaptation and risk mitigation investments capitalize into real estate prices. Equilibrium house prices and investor market share are determined by agents' willingness to pay, influenced by income, coastal living preferences, and beach width.
More Notes: C-HOM models long-term coastal real estate markets, incorporating SLR, storm risk, and subsidies; it identifies policy tradeoffs between slowing demographic transitions and allowing market adjustment to climate risks, finding subsidies dampen the effect of SLR on property values but accelerate gentrification if removed, and considers limitations such as fixed housing supply and linear SLR.
Economic dynamics: Adaptive (reflecting shifts in economic behavior in response to impacts)
Adaptation considered: The analysis extensively considers adaptation through the Coastal Home Ownership Model (C-HOM), a coupled human-natural systems model. It simulates the impact of sea-level rise (SLR) in coastal real estate over 150 years, examining the dynamics of beach nourishment subsidies, local governance decisions, and external market influences. C-HOM compares baseline scenarios with reduced subsidies and varying market conditions, offering insights into long-term coastal management efficiency, equity implications, and the societal trade-offs involved in adaptation strategies.

Paper Title: The short-run, dynamic employment effects of natural disasters: New insights from Puerto Rico
Outcome(s) of Interest: Short-run, dynamic employment effects; Industry-specific employment changes (increases and decreases); Heterogeneity explained by input-output linkages.
Drivers of Risk: Hurricanes; wind speed; county-level exposure; storm index (Sct); Saffir-Simpson scale.
Methodology: The study uses panel local projections on monthly data (1995-2019) for 70 3-digit NAICS industries and 78 Puerto Rican counties to analyze the dynamic employment effects of hurricanes. A continuous treatment measure of wind exposure is constructed using the HURRECON model (adapted from Holland's equation and parameterized following Boose et al. (2004)) and satellite data, incorporating maximum wind speed recorded in each county. An exposure index (𝑆𝑐𝑡) is calculated based on population-weighted county centroids and normalized wind speed. Employment data from the Quarterly Census of Employment and Wages (QCEW) and Local Area Unemployment Statistics from the BLS are used. The analysis involves panel regressions with Newey-West corrected standard errors, controlling for past values of the outcome, time and county fixed effects, and sometimes county-industry and industry-time fixed effects. The methodology exploits county-time, county-industry-time, and industry-time variation, with robustness checks including different exposure measures and specifications. Linear interpolation is applied to approximately 8% of industry-county-time employment and wage observations to address non-disclosure issues. Lags and leads of the exposure measure are included in some specifications.
Highlights: The study analyzes dynamic employment effects of hurricanes in Puerto Rico from 1995-2019, revealing industry-specific impacts with construction and transportation sectors often strengthened, while accommodation and agriculture are weakened. Employment overall decreases by 0.5% post-hurricane, with industry heterogeneity partly due to input-output linkages, adaptability, and varying storm exposure by county and time.
More Notes: The study analyzes the short-run, dynamic employment effects of hurricanes in Puerto Rico from 1995-2017 using monthly data across 70 industries and 78 counties, employing maximum wind speed as an exposure index. Analysis considers employment in the private sector, uses a 64-knot hurricane intensity threshold, and is performed with and without linear interpolation, with results showing sensitivity to interpolation methods. Detailed industry data is crucial, with heterogeneity in employment responses driven by input-output linkages. Figures present results with and without interpolation, analyzing dynamic effects at different horizons.
Adaptation considered: The HURRECON model is adapted and parameterized for Puerto Rico based on prior work (Boose et al., 2004). The analysis controls for pre-trends, seasonal effects, past values and leads of the exposure measure, and various fixed effects.
